children.value:
:
Data transformation is the process of converting data from one form or scale to another to improve analysis and interpretation.
To meet the assumptions of statistical tests,
handle the scale of data range differences,
enhance the performance of machine learning models,

:
Proper data transformation can significantly affect the quality of insights derived from data analysis and modeling.

:
Min-max scaling is a popular data normalization technique that transforms features to fall within a specific range, typically between 0 and 1.

children.html: X′=X−ab−a×(b′−a′)+a′X'=\frac{X-a}{b-a} \times (b' - a') + a'X′=b−aX−a​×(b′−a′)+a′
X′X'X′

children.value: is the scaled value of the feature

children.html: XXX
XXX

children.value: is the original value of the feature.

children.html: aaa

children.value: is the minimum value of the feature across all samples.

children.html: bbb

children.value: is the maximum value of the feature across all samples.

children.html: a′a'a′
b′b'b′

children.value: is the new minimum and maximum values, respectively, for the target range.

children.alt: The histogram (top) and PDF (bottom) of the average subzone resale price before (left) and after (right) min-max scaling.

children.value: The histogram (top) and PDF (bottom) of the average subzone resale price before (left) and after (right) min-max scaling.

:
Standardization (aka Z-score normalization) is a data transformation technique that scales features to have zero mean and unit variance. Its purpose is to make different features comparable by transforming them to a common scale.

children.html: X′=X−μσX' = \frac{X - \mu}{\sigma}X′=σX−μ​
XXX
μ\muμ

children.value: is the mean of the feature values.

children.html: σ\sigmaσ

children.value: is the standard deviation of the feature values.
When working with features measured on different scales (e.g., age, income, and temperature).
When using machine learning algorithms that are sensitive to feature scales, such as linear discriminant analysis, logistic regression, or principal component analysis.

children.alt: The histogram (top) and PDF (bottom) of the average subzone resale price before (left) and after (right) standardization.

children.value: The histogram (top) and PDF (bottom) of the average subzone resale price before (left) and after (right) standardization.

children.alt: The PDF (top) of the average subzone resale price of 3 rooms and 5 rooms HDB flat before (left) and after (right) standardization. The two scatter plots at the bottom show the relationship between 3 and 5 room HDB flat.

children.value: The PDF (top) of the average subzone resale price of 3 rooms and 5 rooms HDB flat before (left) and after (right) standardization. The two scatter plots at the bottom show the relationship between 3 and 5 room HDB flat.
(potentially) Not suitable for data crossing zero

:
Log transformation is a data transformation technique that applies the natural logarithm to the original data.
It helps to reduce skewness in the data and stabilize variance for statistical analysis or modeling.

children.html: Xlog=log⁡(X)X_{\text{log}} = \log(X)Xlog​=log(X)

children.value: could use various base for the log, common options include 2, 10, or e (natural log)
When the data is positively skewed or has a wide range of values.
When the relationship between two variables can be better modeled using a logarithmic scale.

children.alt: The before (left) and after (right) log-transformed of resale prices.

children.value: The before (left) and after (right) log-transformed of resale prices.

children.alt: The before (top) and after (bottom) log-transformed of ridership (arrival passsenger).

children.value: The before (top) and after (bottom) log-transformed of ridership (arrival passsenger).
Can improve linearity in relationships between variables.
Distorts the original scale of data, making interpretation more challenging.
Cannot be applied to negative values or zero.
The choice of logarithm base (e, 2, 10) may affect results and interpretation.

:
Box-Cox transformation is a power transformation technique that can stabilize variance and make data more normally distributed.
It is a family of transformations that includes the logarithmic (

λ=0.5\lambda=0.5λ=0.5
Xbox-cox(λ)=Xλ−1λifλ≠0X_{\text{box-cox}}(\lambda) = \frac{X^\lambda - 1}{\lambda} \quad \text{if} \quad \lambda \neq 0Xbox-cox​(λ)=λXλ−1​ifλ=0
Xbox-cox(λ)=log⁡(X)ifλ=0X_{\text{box-cox}}(\lambda) = \log(X) \quad \text{if} \quad \lambda = 0Xbox-cox​(λ)=log(X)ifλ=0

children.value: When the data is not normally distributed or has varying degrees of skewness or kurtosis.
When trying to linearize relationships between variables or equalize variances across groups.

children.alt: Histogram of Box-Cox transformed values, with \lambda set to: 0, 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2, 3.

children.value: Histogram of Box-Cox transformed values, with

children.html: λ\lambdaλ

children.value: Can handle various degrees of skewness and kurtosis.
Provides flexibility to choose the best transformation based on data characteristics.
Includes logarithmic and square root transformations as special cases.
Requires estimating the optimal lambda parameter, which can be time-consuming.
Loses some interpretability due to data transformation.
May not always provide a significant improvement in data normality.

children.html: λ\lambdaλ

children.value:
:
Ranking data transformation replaces original values with their corresponding ranks, preserving the order or hierarchy of the data.
It can help in data visualization, feature engineering, or non-parametric statistical tests.

:
There is no explicit equation for ranking data transformation. The process involves sorting the values and assigning ranks based on their positions in the sorted list. In case of ties, you can use methods like average, min, or max ranking.

:
When working with ordinal data or categorical data that can be ordered.
When performing non-parametric statistical tests that require ranked data.

children.alt: The relationship between the ranks and the original data, and the frequency distribution of the ranks.

children.value: The relationship between the ranks and the original data, and the frequency distribution of the ranks.
What is the expected frequency distribution? Why is it not exactly the same as the expected distribution?
Simplifies data interpretation by focusing on relative positions.
Can mitigate the impact of outliers.
Loses information about the original magnitude, scale, and internal variation of data.
Sensitive to ties in data, especially when using certain ranking methods.
May not be appropriate for all types of statistical analyses or machine learning algorithms.

:
Examine your dataset for issues like missing values, outliers,
. Identifying these challenges will inform the choice of transformation technique.
. This will help you choose appropriate transformation methods, as some techniques are designed specifically for certain variable types.
Evaluate the goals of your analysis
and the specific requirements of your chosen modeling technique. Different transformations can address particular challenges or better align with specific analysis goals.
transformations for numerical data, and one-hot encoding or ordinal encoding for categorical data.

:
Weight the advantages and disadvantages of different techniques, considering factors like interpretability, ease of implementation, and
on your data and model performance. This will help you identify the most effective approach for your specific situation.
Consult resources and domain experts (expert in GIS)

:
Leverage the knowledge of experienced professionals, peer-reviewed literature, and other credible sources to inform your decision-making process.
